results.title: Flower buds
results.creator_credit: Central Newsreel and Documentary Film Studio of the People's Republic of China
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “China Today”.
This film covers cultural aspects of children’s lives in China such as dance, children’s orchestra, singing, folk-dance, traditional music and instruments. Non-stylised overview of traditional cultural traditions as demonstrated by children.

results.title: Flower blooming seed germinating
results.brief_description: Various unedited time-lapse footage. Shows a flower blooming and excellent footage of seeds germinating and plants breaking through soil. Also contains good leader halfway through film. Nice colours, good to watch.

results.title: Flower
results.brief_description: When Jenova Chen and Nicholas Clark designed Flower, they approached it as more of an interactive artwork than a traditional videogame.

constellations_primary.name: Flower on the wind
constellations_primary.description: Explore the use of flowers in the moving image as an aesthetic and metaphor.

results.description:
When Jenova Chen and Nicholas Clark designed Flower, they approached it as more of an interactive artwork than a traditional videogame.

Flower lets you control the wind as it blows a single flower petal around the stages. The petal interacts with various elements in the world, triggering wind turbines or rejuvenating the landscape.

Rather than focus on traditional design principles of ‘fun’ or challenging gameplay, Chen and Clark instead worked to create a meditative experience they hoped would provoke positive emotions in the player.
description_for_label:
When Jenova Chen and Nicholas Clark designed Flower, they approached it as more of an interactive artwork than a traditional videogame.

Flower lets you control the wind as it blows a single flower petal around the stages. The petal interacts with various elements in the world, triggering wind turbines or rejuvenating the landscape.

Rather than focus on traditional design principles of ‘fun’ or challenging gameplay, Chen and Clark instead worked to create a meditative experience they hoped would provoke positive emotions in the player.

results.title: Florence: cradle of the Renaissance
results.creator_credit: Museum Television Workshop and Leah Joy
results.brief_description: Narrated by Grace Jackman, with poetry and readings inspired by Florence, and read by Richard Levine, viewers are taken on an artistic travelogue of Florence, focusing primarily on the Renaissance. This commentary provides insight into the architectural and artistic wonders which are an integral part of Florence. From 1436 when Brunelleschi designed the dome of Santa Maria del Fiore, the next hundred years of the Renaissance were filled with seminal figures like Michelangelo, Botticelli, Ghiberti, Cellini, Donatello and Leonardo da Vinci; overlooked by the great patrons Cosimo and Lorenzo de Medici. This video enables the viewer to experience the masterpieces of Florence as an armchair traveller.

results.title: Florence [Videogame Archive]
results.brief_description:
Expertly blending the visual novel and gaming genres, Florence illustrates one year in the life of a young woman in Melbourne as she falls in love, breaks her daily routine and follows her creative passion.

Developed by Australian craft games studio Mountains, Florence uses innovative gameplay mechanics to represent social interactions. The emotions of the poignant narrative are rendered through tapping and swiping minigames, making them all the more touching.

The archive spans a variety of paraphernalia from Florence’s creation, including storyboards, early character designs, unused game concepts, musical samples and feedback from game testers. It provides invaluable insight on the game development process and the path Mountains took in making their award-winning game.

results.title: Floral tapestry
results.creator_credit: Central Coast Media, Mark Falzon and Michael Edols
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Host Sue Henckel rekindles her passion for wildflowers while touring through two parks. She also visits artist and philosopher William Ricketts whose sculptures in the 1930’s expressed his understanding of the Aborigines’ relationship to the environment. She also meets the descendants of the artist’s subjects who as commercial artists in the 90’s continue to express their relationship to the landscape and plant life.

results.title: Flora: scenes from a leadership convention
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Arthur Hammond, Roman Kroitor, Michael McKennirey and Peter Raymont
results.brief_description: A fresh, incisive look at Canadian politics, this film penetrates the surface glitter of the 1976 Progressive Conservative Party leadership convention, focusing on the campaign of Cape Bretoner Flora MacDonald, the first woman to contest her party’s leadership. (Follow-up film: Reflections on a Leadership Convention.)
